In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the solution in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(input_str::String, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(input_str, " ")
    output_str = ""
    line_length = 0
    
    for word in words
        if line_length + length(word) > text_width
            output_str *= "\n"
            line_length = 0
        elseif !isempty(output_str)
            output_str *= " "
            line_length += 1
        end
        
        output_str *= word
        line_length += length(word)
    end
    
    return output_str
end
```
This function splits the input string into words and iterates over each word. If adding a new word would exceed `text_width`, it starts a new line. It also adds a space between words, unless it's the first word on a line. The resulting string is then returned. 

Here is an example:
```julia
println(wrap_string("Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit"))
```
This will output:
```
Lorem ipsum
dolor sit
amet, consectetur
adipiscing elit
```
